components.name: AboutPage
components.templateData:
About Skelify

Learn more about our mission and our team.

What is Skelify?

Skelify is a smart skeleton generator designed to accelerate the software development lifecycle. By automating the repetitive and time-consuming tasks of project setup and configuration, Skelify allows developers to focus on what matters most: building great software.

Our Mission

Our mission is to provide a powerful and flexible tool that enforces best practices, ensures consistency across projects, and dramatically reduces the time it takes to get from idea to a working skeleton.

Our Team

Skelify is built by a passionate team of developers at ELCA.

components.name: DownloadModal
components.templateData:
@if (isOpen()) {

Download Project

Your project is ready to be downloaded as a ZIP file. This will include:

  • Complete source code skeleton
  • Docker configuration files
  • CI/CD pipeline configurations
  • Database migration scripts
  • Documentation and README files
  • Security and authentication setup

This is a POC demo - in production, this would trigger the actual project generation and download.

}

components.template:

import { Component, Input, Output, EventEmitter } from '@angular/core'; import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common'; import { ButtonComponent } from './button.component'; import type { User } from './user'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-header', standalone: true, imports: [CommonModule, ButtonComponent], template: `

Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
`, styleUrls: ['./header.css'], }) export class HeaderComponent { @Input() user: User | null = null; @Output() onLogin = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onLogout = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onCreateAccount = new EventEmitter(); }

components.name: LandingPage
components.templateData:
Skelify

Accelerate your development lifecycle with intelligent project skeleton generator

Configurable

Set all your project information like project name, description, naming convention.

Technology Stack

Choose your technologies to build your stack on frontend, backend or mobile.

Infrastructure

Select your preferred CI/CD, containerization, and quality tools to fit your workflow.

How It Works

1

Select Your Stack

Choose your preferred technologies from the list.

2

Configure Infrastructure

Set up your CI/CD, containerization, and quality tools.

3

Generate & Download

Get a complete codebase skeleton in minutes.

components.name: LayoutHorizontal
PageComponent
components.template:
Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
components.sourceCode:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common'; import { HeaderComponent } from './header.component'; import type { User } from './user'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-page', standalone: true, imports: [CommonModule, HeaderComponent], template: `

Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
`, styleUrls: ['./page.css'], }) export class PageComponent { user: User | null = null; doLogout() { this.user = null; } doLogin() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } doCreateAccount() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } }

components.name: ReviewStep
components.templateData:
@if (wizardState.isLoading()) {

Generating your project, please wait...

} @else if (wizardState.isGenerated()) {

Project Generated!

Congratulations! Your project is ready for download.

} @else {

Review Your Configuration

Project Information

Project Name: {{ wizardState.projectInfo().projectName }}

Description: {{ wizardState.projectInfo().projectDescription }}

Organization: {{ wizardState.projectInfo().organization }}

Package Name: {{ wizardState.projectInfo().packageName }}

Technology Stack

Backend: {{ wizardState.techStack().backend }}

Frontend: {{ wizardState.techStack().frontend }}

Mobile: {{ wizardState.techStack().mobile }}

Database: {{ wizardState.techStack().database }}

Infrastructure

CI/CD: {{ wizardState.infrastructure().ci_cd.join(', ') }}

Containerization: {{ wizardState.infrastructure().containerization.join(', ') }}

Quality: {{ wizardState.infrastructure().quality.join(', ') }}

Security: {{ wizardState.infrastructure().security.join(', ') }}

}

variables.name: appConfig
AppConstants
authConfig
variables.defaultValue:
{
  config: {
              authority: 'http://localhost:8444/realms/skelify',
              redirectUrl: window.location.origin,
              postLogoutRedirectUri: window.location.origin,
              clientId: 'skelify',
              scope: 'openid profile email offline_access',
              responseType: 'code',
              silentRenew: true,
              useRefreshToken: true,
              renewTimeBeforeTokenExpiresInSeconds: 30,
              logLevel: environment.production ? LogLevel.None : LogLevel.None,
          }
}
